body:
TopFieldCollector still has a Java-style create method (with lower case 'c')
I'll submit a patch that changes it and all references to it.

by lvl

Thanks. Patch applied in revision 1347715

by ccurrens

This requires too much of an API change to implement in 3.0.3. Unassigning from 3.0.3, and we can revisit it in a later release.

by ccurrens

Moving to 3.5

by ccurrens

This was fixed in LUCENE-4208 and pushed to Lucene.Net (the tests you touched were removed anyway). Spatial4n was updated separately to version 0.3, which will be on nuget shortly.

Pulled commit 3b39ac2a, thanks for spotting that
The parameter class no longer exists, so this can be closed

It would be awesome if formatting commits could be done different from functionality commits, so only the later need to be reviewed. Anyhow, in `MultiStringIndexCache.CreateValue` seems to use `List<Int32>[] retArray` for an lookup of documentId => list-if-indexes pointing to `String[] mterms`. (I like the idea of a value pool to perform something similar to interning.) However, the `mterms` array is initiated with `new String[reader.MaxDoc + 1]`, it will not support cases where a reader have more unique terms than documents (you silently break out from that in line 920).
Sorry for lots of formatting in logical commit. I'd fix it. Also I'd add support for cases where a reader have more unique terms than documents, as you said.

Prescott, this was discussed before in the mailing list. Are there any known issues at this point?

Next step for me is to try and run in on my Windows 8 machine, but first I want to understand what I'm getting myself into...

by itamar
Please post such question to out mailing list
@sisve have you looked at this? are we good for pulling this in (probably need to go through the mailing list first, tho)

A quick check shows that the issues regarding mterms is fixed. I've got some (perhaps mental) issues with the public order-field of MultiStringIndex. It seems to be some kind of lookup from FacetCollector.Collect (documentId => stringValues[]), but the fact that it's a public field, and named order, makes my insides itch. (I'm itchy that way...)
I think you are right. Something in the way this PR is done highlights bad API on our part. I think it would be best to differ this to v4 where we are more flexible on making API changes.
Closing this via commit, nothing to do here
We are starting to look at this now, mainly by looking at this changeset https://github.com/cyberram/lucene.net/tree/branch_4x
Did anyone get a chance to review my changes?
Good job! That is what every lucene.net guy was secretly waiting for.
Hi, which version of Lucene did you port this code from?
Starting to review this now. Thanks for the effort.

Ported it from 4.3.
Used the code from 
https://github.com/apache/lucene-solr/tree/lucene_solr_4_3/lucene/spatial/src/java/org/apache/lucene/spatial

Do we have an ICLA on file from you?

http://www.apache.org/licenses/icla.txt
No. Just now submitted it.

I built on top of this work but still a lot to do to make all tests green.

Now waiting for the status of the CCLA to be cleared up, in the meantime work is being done on my fork https://github.com/synhershko/lucene.net/tree/Lucene.Net_4.8.0
Just received a confirmation that my ICLA has been filled.
Thanks, I'll be reviewing this shortly
All merged now, thanks
@cyberram do you still have this branch locally? I can't merge it if you dont...

Oops. Sorry was preparing my repo for the 4.8.0 testing and I think I
accidentally removed my other branch.
I do have it in my local.

Have created another pull request for it now.
https://github.com/apache/lucene.net/pull/20

Cheers,

Cheers,
Ramkumar.K

I think this is invalid now as we are working against master and working on version 4.8. Can anyone confirm? Trying to clean up the pull requests here
@synhershko @azubanov  Is this still valid?
Please leave open, there are some valid fixes there. Will attend to this soon.

We will need you to submit a CLA to Apache please, and confirm back with us when it is properly filed.

Actually not everything here is "long fixed", I'll pull the remaining bits soon
Merged, thanks

Merged, thanks.

Can you please send another PR which moves the Facet tests into their own Test project (`src\Lucene.Net.Tests.Facet`)?
you're correct. facets in wrong directory, please move to src.
Thanks, will review shortly. Do you have an ICLA with Apache?
Quick note: `KNearestNeighborClassifier` is misspelled `KNearesteighborClassifier`

I made a number of comments while looking at the wrong java code - apologies for that. I have removed them and will re-review. 

Java code here: http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/lucene/dev/branches/lucene_solr_4_8/lucene/classification/src/java/org/apache/lucene/classification/
Itamar, I emailed a signed ICLA this morning. Let me know if there is anything else to do.
Hi, do you have a CLA with Apache?
I do.

Any chance you can rebase this to be against master? I basically just copied spatial there (https://github.com/apache/lucenenet/tree/master/src/contrib/Spatial) and I'd like to pull all the pending PRs we have against that in before doing more necessary porting work on it. Thanks.
Sure can. Will do it soon.

Thanks, pulling this in now. Any chance you could port the tests as well? Simple copy/paste from Java with minor fixes should do, no need for styling there. I'll try getting some guidance on that posted.
Merged, thanks
Pulling in, thanks
Looks good, let us know when its ready to merge!

If it looks good to you, I say go ahead and merge. Most of the times TestGraphTokenizer tests now pass. In certain conditions we still encounter failures but they are not related to the MockReaderWrapper anymore.
Good catch, keep them coming! :)

Looks good, thanks.

There's still a failure in `TestRandomRegexps`, and I pushed another fix relating to NRE I see being thrown.

There are some related failures in the code base, for example `TestUTF32ToUTF8` and IIRC around the FST tests as well (tho they seem to be passing now). I was trying to solve them using CodePoint methods but maybe your approach could work there as well. Can you have a look?

I will take a look at the failure with TestRandomRegexps, perhaps there are other randomly invoked execution paths that I did not run into that are generating the failures. Did not get "lucky" enough, I guess.

As to the related to the code point failures, definitely will take a look.
Merged now, thanks!
Why won't we override Equals as well? why use a dedicated method for this?

Let me know what you had in mind specifically. I don't see a good way to override .NET's built in HashSet equals behavior and not sure creating our own Set class that inherits .NET but overrides equals is worth the trouble if it will only help with the test in question.
You are right, there doesn't seem to be a better way to do this

In Java, the .NET UnauthorizedAccessException extends IOException in Java (see http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/file/AccessDeniedException.html) so Execption catching works in Windows.

Windows is the only platform where fsync on directories does not work, but we still try! We know for sure that it works in MacOSX and Linux, so we assert on that, but we don't check it in production, because later/earlier versions of those operating systems may not implement it. So the whole thing is "the best we can do".

@uschindler yes that was our understanding (see mail thread), and thanks for confirming that. Why the effort for fsync'ing a dir in the first place though?

Since Windows doesn't support this, and the CLR doesn't seem to have a way of doing that (probably as a result), shouldn't we be ok with just fsyncing all files in a Directory and be done with it?

fsync on directory is more than fsyncing all files in it (there is a difference between syncing metadata and syncing buffers). Mike McCandless did tests on Linux (he has a machine that he hardly switched off in a loop with remote hardware power plug) and he tested it: When machine came up, index was still alive (he tested Linux).

Fsync on directory flushes the file buffers of the directory _\+ its metadata_. The first one is also done by syncing metadata of a file contained, yes that works, but the directory's metadata is not necessarily written. Because of that it could happen that the inode of the directory is there, but the entry in the parent directory not yet (because the directory's metadata was not yet synced). After hard kill of machine, the fsck will report a lost+found inode (the directory). Because of the lost dir entry, the directory itsself is not visible in its parent.

I would still try to fsync also in windows, maybe it works at some time. And this is what we are doing in Lucene Java - we just try the POSIX semantics, which _may_ work on Windows. So it is just best effort.

This is why we fsync on directory, too: http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/fsync.2.html

"Calling fsync() does not necessarily ensure that the entry in the
       directory containing the file has also reached disk.  For that an
       explicit fsync() on a file descriptor for the directory is also
       needed."

Ok @laimis, so to enable better support of Mono on non-Windows OSs lets bring back this for dirs as well, however lets make 2 changes: (1) handle UnauthorizedAccessException the same as IOException, (2) if its a folder on a Windows OS don't retry (lets avoid IW.Commit slowness for the common use case).

Thanks @uschindler, this makes sense, although all of that doesn't apply to Windows really :)

We'll be bringing this back for the sake of better non-Windows support through Mono

In Lucene 5, the fsync on directory may be more important, be cause we rely on NIO.2's atomic rename functionality (we changed commit logic to make use of that). So we fsync on the direcory after the atomic rename of the commit (segments) file.
Oh dear. We'll cross that bridge when we get there :)

I noticed something: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa365258(v=vs.85).aspx

It says, you can only open a direcory with FILE_FLAG_BACKUP_SEMANTICS... Maybe this is why its causing "AccessDenied". 
But on the other hand, the list of functions to call do not contain FlushFileBuffers! So it might be useless.

Unfortunately, we cannot do this from Java NIO.2, but you may try this from .NET:

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa363858(v=vs.85).aspx
@synhershko sounds good, will bring back the fsync support for directories, will do so in a separate branch / PR. Thanks guys!

In case anyone needs faceted search before Lucene.Net 4.8 is available, I have just completed a .NET port of version 3.2.0 of the BoboBrowse faceted search engine, which is implemented on top of Lucene.Net, and compatible with Lucene.Net 3.0.3.

NuGet package (pre-release): https://www.nuget.org/packages/BoboBrowse.Net/
Documentation: https://github.com/NightOwl888/BoboBrowse.Net/wiki
Repository: https://github.com/NightOwl888/BoboBrowse.Net

It is currently in beta. All unit tests are passing, and it has worked flawlessly in the 3 projects I have tested it with. However, I am seeking a wider test audience in order to make certain it is stable before the official release.

Please report any issues you find (or just report in if you can't find any issues) on GitHub: https://github.com/NightOwl888/BoboBrowse.Net/issues

Thanks
Let me reopen a different PR, it will be cleaner after the rebase. Too many of the merge branch 'master' here...
@laimis nice. You should note we have a class `Collections` with implementations of unmodifiable\* stuff based on the BCL
@geobmx540 I think we can close this in favor of moving forward with 4.8? backward support for v3 is dropped in favor of putting all resources in pushing v4 forward
Agreed @synhershko

@synhershko yeah, saw that but could not use it because it does items.ToArray() initialization of the immutable list, in essence losing the reference to the items list passed to it. The same issue that original code was suffering from. The code in that class could be a little bit better in how it passes data around, but since it is somewhat isolated, kept the code structure the same and just fixed the issue and moved on.
Merging now - will this get us below 150 failures? :)
No need to port `Numeric` IMO, all usages I've seen of it mattered only for inheritance which I could get by one way or another.

@synhershko ha! We wish. If I had to guess it will get us down to 220 range, you know how those random tests go. But what it will allow me to do is move on to the next failures. This particular issue had me stomped. It is so subtle, I just couldn't see what was wrong until looking at the byte level of what the index streams are writing... it was brutal.
@laimis you're a committer, you should be able to commit without a PR - unless you just want to review :)
I'm good with this process - let's always have an extra set of eyes for intrusive changes
I like it.

@synhershko @geobmx540 I like the PR approach too. So if you guys don't mind it either, let's continue that way. I am still new with this code base so it is good to have someone look over the changes.

Hopefully the explanations are useful. Let me know if you want me to change anything.
Let me know when its ready to be reviewed an merged?

I used to merge to master as I went - since Codecs is outside of the rest of your guy's flow. I decided it was right to jump on the PR bandwagon. 

Up to you, I can keep this outstanding as I continue to port, or we can review / merge it in, and I can continue to port. I don't mind, as long as nobody else is working on Codecs it probably doesn't matter too much
Looks good. I merged now because you were working off master - please create a branch for future PRs :)
The tests package should be renamed (`git mv`ed) to be Lucene.Net.Tests.Codecs

Absolutely welcome - 

You should sign up for the wiki and makes adjustments to the getting started section - probably would be useful to break it into a few sections based on all Itamar wrote
Glad it's welcome! Once I have it here I'm happy to port it to there. Have a few irons in the fire right now but I'm sure I can make it happen.

@geobmx540 cleaned up version is ready for review. **NOTE:** I'm working on my ICLA right now.
- Removed "Work in Progress" from title
- Updated the PR to include what it's trying to achieve
- All of the initial formatting is done
- Content changes kept to a minimum (except language changes around moving to friendly links, etc.
FYI, my ICLA has now been submitted to Apache with a request to notify Lucene.net.

Both you and the committer group will get notice once the secretary has handled that - thanks!

I have a question that's probably general - more of style. Do we want to want to include a lot of the details here in the repo vs the wiki?

I lean towards making this much more of a summary and then pointing it to various parts of the wiki (getting started is now 4 different sub pages - in my attempt to break it up).

I'm open to what people think?

It's a good question. Personally, when I approach a repo as a developer, I hope to see three things:
- A readme describing the project with some links, etc.
- A license file so I know what terms I'm working under
- Something that quickly tells me how to get started, and where my efforts would be well spent. 

A contributor's guide, IMO, makes the most sense closest to the contributions, and in this case, that's Github. That's why it felt natural to put it here rather than in the Wiki. 

Definitely a good idea to sort that preference out first, though.

Thanks Sean

We may want to include some explanation on the folder structure, as well as probably removing the current status of things (which is bound to change)

@synhershko happy to remove the "current status" aspects if you want; let me know. I was thinking it makes sense to keep them there until such a time as they maybe were broken up into GitHub issues that could be tagged with `up-for-grabs`. 

A future PR could easily remove them from the guide. However, I think it still represents the best place and piece of information for someone to get started. I actually really liked that; without an issues list, it's nice to have something to point towards a "good place to start".
I'm all in for the `up-for-grabs` thing, and would have done it already if we had github issues enabled..

FYI, Apache just notified me that my ICLA has been processed and we're all good there.

If someone enables the issues, I'd be happy to try to translate some of the items here and then remove them in a separate PR.

For now, I think it makes sense to leave it all here and push it as-is so at least a dev can get all the information in one spot.
Is there another project that has github issues enabled I can look at? Or I can email infra and see what they say
Email Infra, I think no Apache project has it enabled. There's JIRA for that :(

Apache has this pattern of maintaining all data related to projects in house. 

Hence, mailing lists instead of google hangouts, hosted jira, etc. There are some tools that will push issues from Jira to Github issues and separate tools to push Github issues to Jira.  It may be worth using a win / win  request of enabling issues and pushing issues into Jira.

Thanks for this PR

Can you please resend this PR, this time with only the Expressions bits (code + tests), and also rebase this against the current master so there are no merge conflicts?

It will be probably easier for you to create a new branch following apache/master and copying just the Expression projects files over, committing and pushing that
So given that those are separate issues, can we get this one merged in as is and go from there?
Get you git squash please?
